lead_paragraph: A majority of Republican primary voters view their party as divided, while Democratic voters see their side as unified, according to a New York Times/CBS News national poll.

byline.contributor: Marina Stefan, Dalia Sussman and Giovanni Russonello contributed reporting.
byline.original: By PATRICK HEALY and MEGAN THEE-BRENAN

headline.print_headline: Most Republicans Say ’16 Race Is Embarrassing
headline.main: Most Republicans Feel Embarrassed by Campaign, Poll Says

snippet: A majority of Republican primary voters view their party as divided, while Democratic voters see their side as unified, according to a New York Times/CBS News national poll.
abstract: New York Times/CBS News national poll finds that majority of Republican primary voters view their party as divided and source of embarrassment, while Democratic primary voters see their side as unified; also finds that 46 percent of Republican primary voters favor Donald J Trump for president now that several of his rivals have left race, while Democrats remain split almost evenly between Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders.
